autoAppliedRules.name: User AI Instruction
autoAppliedRules.content:
âœ… Full Tech Stack for Your Smart Personal Finance & Investment Manager
Area	Technologies	Purpose
Core Language	Java 17+	Main development
UI	JavaFX	Desktop GUI
Data Storage	SQLite (local), MySQL/PostgreSQL (cloud/web)	Persist transactions, user data
Build Tool	Maven or Gradle	Dependency management
Charting	JavaFX Charts or JFreeChart	Dashboard visualization
API Calls	Java HttpClient, Retrofit (optional)	Fetch stock/ETF data
Machine Learning	Weka or custom Java logic	Risk profile analyzer
PDF/CSV Export	Apache PDFBox / iText (PDF), OpenCSV	Financial report export
Authentication	Custom login system (hashed passwords, Java Crypto), or Firebase/Auth0 (web version)	Secure login
Notifications	JavaFX Alert, desktop notifications (java.awt.SystemTray)	Budget/investment alerts
Scheduling	ScheduledExecutorService, Quartz Scheduler	Auto data refresh, alerts
Optional Web Version	Spring Boot + Thymeleaf (or REST + React)	If you want to turn this into a web app later

âœ… Mapping Features to Technologies
ðŸ” 1. User Authentication
Feature	Tools
Secure login/signup	JavaFX form + hashed passwords (e.g., SHA-256 with salt)
Session management	Store current user ID/session info in memory or DB

ðŸ’¸ 2. Add/Edit/Delete Transactions
Feature	Tools
Form UI	JavaFX
Storage	SQLite / MySQL
Date input	JavaFX DatePicker

ðŸ“ 3. Categorize Transactions
Feature	Tools
Manual	Dropdown in JavaFX
Auto	Keyword mapping logic in Java

ðŸ“Š 4. Dashboard with Charts
Feature	Tools
Monthly Spending / Income vs Expenses	JavaFX LineChart / BarChart / PieChart
Savings Growth	LineChart with time series data

ðŸ”” 5. Budget Setup & Alerts
Feature	Tools
Budget input	JavaFX input fields
Alerts	JavaFX Alert or tray popup using SystemTray
Auto-check	ScheduledExecutorService to compare actual vs. budget regularly

ðŸ” 6. Recurring Expense Handling
Feature	Tools
Pattern recognition	Java logic: group transactions by name/date interval
Auto-categorization	Identify frequency (e.g., same vendor every 30 days)

ðŸ“¤ 7. Export to CSV / PDF
Feature	Tools
CSV	OpenCSV
PDF	iText or Apache PDFBox

ðŸ’° Investment Features
ðŸ§  1. AI-Based Risk Profile Analyzer
Feature	Tools
Risk quiz	JavaFX form
Analysis	Java logic or Weka ML model
Result categories	Conservative, Moderate, Aggressive

ðŸ“Œ Store results for future recommendations.

ðŸ“ˆ 2. Safe Stocks & ETF Recommender
Feature	Tools
Data	Finnhub API / Alpha Vantage
Fetching	Java HttpClient, JSON parsing
Logic	Filter by market cap, beta, volume, dividend
UI	ListView or CardView in JavaFX showing suggestions with short descriptions

ðŸ“Š 3. Auto-Invest Planner
Feature	Tools
Surplus calculation	Total Income - Total Expense
Suggestions	Rule-based logic based on risk profile
UI	Monthly suggestion popups or sidebar panel

ðŸ“š 4. "Learn While You Invest"
Feature	Tools
Tips data	JSON file or embedded DB table
Display	Tooltips in JavaFX, or context-aware popups

ðŸ”” 5. Smart Alerts for Investment Opportunities
Feature	Tools
Polling	ScheduledExecutorService fetches API data
Conditions	e.g., "Stock X dropped 5%"
Alerts	JavaFX or SystemTray popup
Storage	Save alert history in SQLite

ðŸ—‚ Folder Structure Example
pgsql
Copy
Edit

ðŸš€ Suggested Roadmap to Build
Phase 1: Core Personal Finance
 User Auth (Login/Register)

 Add/Edit/Delete Transactions

 Categorize & Store Transactions

 Dashboard Charts

 Budget Setup & Alerts

Phase 2: Advanced Automation
 Recurring Expense Detection

 Export to PDF/CSV

 Notifications via tray or in-app

Phase 3: Investment Module
 Risk Profiler

 Safe Stock Recommender

 Auto-Invest Planner

 Investment Education Tips

 Real-time Alerts

ðŸ”§ Tools & Libraries Summary
Area	Tool
UI	JavaFX
Charts	JavaFX, JFreeChart
Data Storage	SQLite, H2 (dev), MySQL (prod)
API	Finnhub, Alpha Vantage
JSON	org.json, Jackson, or Gson
Scheduling	ScheduledExecutorService
CSV	OpenCSV
PDF	iText, Apache PDFBox
ML	Weka (risk analysis)
Authentication	Java MessageDigest or bcrypt (JBCrypt)
Logging	SLF4J + Logback (make sure that these features are perfectly working)

content.text: The error is: "Cannot resolve method 'searchClient' in 'DriverDatabase'". Looking at the code, in depositController.java, line 55: databaseDriver.searchClient(searchText)
Found the DatabaseDriver.java file. Now I need to view it to see what methods are available.

Looking at the DatabaseDriver class, there is no method called `searchClient`. The available methods related to clients are:


## Examining DatabaseDriver class  
- Found no method named `searchClient` in the DatabaseDriver class.  
- Identified available client-related methods: `getClientsData(String payeeAddress, String password)` and `getAllClientsData`.

Good, I've added the searchClient method to DatabaseDriver. It uses a LIKE query to search for payee addresses that contain the search.
 text  
- The method uses a LIKE query to match addresses containing the search text.

## Implementing Search Functionality  
- Added a searchClient method to DatabaseDriver for finding payee addresses.  
- Placed the searchClient method after getAllClientsData and before delete in the code structure.

Perfect! I've the added missing `searchClient` method to the `DatabaseDriver class`. This method performs a search partial on the `Address`Payee column a using LIKE query, allowing for flexible searching where the text entered can match any part of the payee address.

The method:
- Takes a `payeeAddress` parameter (the search text)
- Uses a prepared statement to safely query the database
- Returns a `ResultSet` containing matching client records with the expected columns (`FirstName`, `LastName`, `PayeeAddress`)
- Handles SQL exceptions gracefully

Now your `depositController.java` should compile successfully, and the search functionality for payees will work as intended. The search will find clients whose payee addresses contain the entered search text, making it easier to locate specific accounts for deposits.

diffs.patch:
@@ -6613,32 +6613,469 @@
 null;%0D%0A    %7D%0D%0A%0D%0A
+    public ResultSet searchClient(String payeeAddress) %7B%0D%0A        try %7B%0D%0A            String query = %22SELECT * FROM Clients WHERE PayeeAddress LIKE ?%22;%0D%0A            PreparedStatement stmt = connection.prepareStatement(query);%0D%0A            stmt.setString(1, %22%25%22 + payeeAddress + %22%25%22);%0D%0A            return stmt.executeQuery();%0D%0A        %7D catch (SQLException e) %7B%0D%0A            e.printStackTrace();%0D%0A        %7D%0D%0A        return null;%0D%0A    %7D%0D%0A%0D%0A
     public boole
